how would you describe your main use cas: As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content);Worldbuilding (e.g. for role-playing games);Narrative fiction writing (either supporting its creation or directly writing in TiddlyWiki)
putting it all together, what value does: It lets me keep all my notes in one, well-structured, easy-to-edit place; remix content and display it in different formats via programmatic templates; and visualize, search, and manipulate data.
what is your level of ability with tiddl: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I am comfortable using WikiText widgets (e.g. <$transclude>, <$list>...);I am comfortable writing filter expressions;I have written custom HTML;I have written custom CSS styles
how do you save changes in tiddlywiki?: Single-file wiki with custom saver (e.g. TiddlyPWA, Timimi, tw5-browser-nativesaver)
how do you back up/sync changes between: No automatic sync across my devices

outside of plugins, palettes and other i:
- many custom stylesheets
- a number of edit toolbar buttons not listed above
- replaced select field input areas with textareas via Field Editor cascade
- heavy use of the ViewTemplate and EditTemplate cascades
- many macros/functions/procedures
- modified $link widget
what are we doing well? prompts for thin:
I love how easy TW makes it to edit (nearly) anything, including itself. I'm also boundlessly grateful to the community for their generosity with their time and their own code, which continues to aid and inspire my work. I've very confident I could not have reached my current proficiency without their help.

Of the future features I've seen mentioned, I'm most excited for multi-value variables and increased flexibility in procedure syntax.
what could we do better? prompts for thi: I'm slightly concerned about what I perceive as an increased reliance on AI assistance, both in coding (some users actively recommend using AI to write and publish plugins for public use) and in branding (like the new AI-generated version logo). I feel that it both undermines the long-standing TW principle that users should own their data and risks the proliferation of bad code by publishers who don't understand it well enough to fix it.
with your consent, we would like to publ: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
title: Community Survey 2025 Answer 00003
